reviewText:
I'm giving this five stars based solely on the fact that this is one of my favorite Ginger Rogers movies.  It was really her first starring role in an "A" picture.  Miss Rogers is stunning in her beauty and charm in this sort of dual character performance.  This songs by Jerome Kern and Dorothy Fields are some of the best of Ginger's career, and her delivery of them is beautiful and soulful.  This movie is very "meta" in that there seems to be a semi-autobiographical element.  Carol Corliss' career seemed to really mirror Ginger's career at the time.
My only complaint is that this film is not available in the United States.  As an American, I'm super annoyed that a film by my favorite actress, who is the epitome of the all-American girl, is not available here in the US.  Annoyed that I have to watch this wonderfully American film through Spanish subtitles.  Makes absolutely no sense.  Come on US film distributors, get it together.  The same thing can be said for Miss Rogers' other films 'Tender Comrade' and 'Professional Sweetheart', which are also only available in region 2 Spanish.

I love this movie, it's storyline is light and fluffy but watching a delightfully young Ginger Rogers strut her stuff is so entertaining. And even though this is a VHS tape the quality is very good. I have a Spanish released Disc but am unable to remove the subtitles, so this was my next choice to see this rare movie. Come on commercial release companies, get your act together and get these rare Movies of Ginger Rogers out onto the market place.

Fresh off her 1935 triumph with Fred Astaire in (TOP HAT, Ginger Rogers had star billing for IN PERSON. She plays here an actress who suffers from agoraphobia after a nervous breakdown. Using false buckteeth and eyeglasses to disguise her notoriety, Ginger heads off to the mountains with a businessman she's just met (George Brent). A fine little musical screwball comedy, with a few songs by Oscar Levant and Dorothy Fields and dances choreographed by Hermes Pan. Related items: (CAREFREE (1938) - Fred Astaire is the psychoanalyst, Rogers the patient who undergoes hypnotism under his watch. Alan Mowbray (Jay Holmes) is delightful as the over-the-top title character in THE VILLAIN STILL PURSUED HER (1940). His co-star: Buster Keaton. Parenthetical number preceding title is a 1 to 10 IMDb viewer poll rating. (6.1) In Person (1935) - Ginger Rogers/George Brent/Alan Mowbray/Grant Mitchell/Samuel S. Hinds/Joan Breslau/Louis Mason/Spencer Charters

This is a wonderfully funny and pleasant romantic comedy, which is under-appreciated today.  No high-quality dvd release from a major US studio exists, which is a shame because "In Person" shows Ginger Rogers at the peak of her beauty, in a plot that allows her to display all of her many talents, including singing and dancing.  And George Brent unbends and gives a fine comedic performance of a man who falls in love with a movie star but pretends not to so that her head won't get any more swelled than it already is!

This Spanish dvd offered by vendor DaaVeeDee is the best version of the movie ever made available.  Although the film has not been restored, it is of good quality visually, the sound is excellent, and there is included a fantastic booklet (in Spanish) about the film and its importance for Rogers' career, the stars and supporting cast, and the director, with excellent glossy photos and lobby cards.  The dvd is Region 2, so requires an all-region or PAL player.

Fresh off her 1935 triumph with Fred Astaire in TOP HAT (VHS edition) (DVD edition), Ginger Rogers had star billing for IN PERSON. She plays here an actress who suffers from agoraphobia after a nervous breakdown. Using false buckteeth and eyeglasses to disguise her notoriety, Ginger heads off to the mountains with a businessman she's just met (George Brent). A fine little musical screwball comedy, with a few songs by Oscar Levant and Dorothy Fields and dances choreographed by Hermes Pan. As of 1/09, IN PERSON was not available on DVD. Related items: CAREFREE (1938) - Fred Astaire is the psychoanalyst, Rogers the patient who undergoes hypnotism under his watch.
